awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Exploring Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Enabled Skills Data For Education-to-Employment Transitions and Career Support
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to empower individuals to thrive in a world of innovative disruption through the development of an enduring, data-driven, ready-access digital service that will assist learners to identify opportunity pathways throughout a lifetime of learning and employment. Completion of this project and the addition of the proposed analytical capabilities applied to learner narratives may create a powerful and unique set of tools for individuals, secondary and higher educational institutions, employers, and a range of informal education providers. The research completed in this project and tools produced by it seek to inform a new approach to matching the interests, skills and educational backgrounds of learners to jobs and educational opportunities. This approach engages learners of diverse backgrounds early in their education and assists them in succeeding in many fields that currently suffer from lack of diversity, especially in the STEM disciplines. Better matching of skills and interests to learning trajectories and career options may enhance human development broadly, increase job satisfaction, and lead to a more productive workforce. 
 
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project seeks to develop methods for bringing a wide range of learner interests and achievements into a common framework that will be used to match a learner’s current state to specific opportunities and general development pathways.  The project also seeks to assess the value of opportunities and chance of success for the student. This research centers on machine analysis of written reflections. Findings digitally mined from written reflections and potentially from other kinds of narrative artifacts are combined with data from grades, test scores, and other skills assessments and certifications to guide learners toward attractive educational and employment opportunities. In addition, findings from interactive visualization tools support human exploratory analyses of machine categorizations in order to improve the delivery of educational programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Title: Exploring the Potential for Artificial Intelligence-enabled Skills Data to Add Value to the Education-to-Employment Transition and to Enhance Career and Professional Development

 

Imagine a world where individuals embark on careers that align perfectly with their passions, skills and interests. Envision someone who unexpectedly loses their job, feeling disheartened and uncertain about their future. However, their despair turns into hope when they discover a transformative, video-based platform that uses innovative Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven strategies to help them identify a better job fit. This tool will not only guide them towards more fulfilling opportunities but also highlight any additional education or training needed and provide recommendations on where to obtain it.

 

To bring this reality to fruition, we need a user-friendly tool and process that is readily available and provides tailored guidance along educational and career pathways. In today's fast-paced world, where change is constant, our platform will assist individuals in navigating transitions while tailoring recommendations based on their unique desires, skills, motivations, and circumstances.

 

Our research presents a promising path toward realizing this vision by harnessing the power of AI combined with network analysis in a unique manner. We conducted a novel study that explored the capabilities of AI combined with network analysis to extract insights from reflective narratives provided by college students at the University of Central Oklahoma (UCO). These narratives, which had been pre-assessed by trained faculty for levels of personal insight, formed a rich database that was scanned by the AI to test its ability to produce useful information for each individual learner, as well as for different student groups categorized through narrative analysis. The findings from this AI scanning were confirmed by the UCO unit, which actively promotes the development of students' critical self-reflective capacities throughout their academic journey.

 

The integration of these AI-driven techniques into the talent matching process holds tremendous promise for the future. By effectively aligning skills with individual aspirations and industry demands, we can enhance student outcomes, employability, talent development, and industry relevance. Individuals will be better equipped to navigate the complexities of the job market, armed with the knowledge and skills necessary for success. Furthermore, our approach and tools address the prevalent skills gap, ensuring that skills align with real-world job requirements and opportunities. These advancements stand to not only benefit students but also contribute to a more efficient and productive workforce.

 

The benefits of this research extend beyond the individual level. By empowering individuals to find careers that align with their passions, skills and interests, we foster a happier, more engaged workforce. When people are doing work, they find meaningful, job productivity and satisfaction increase, leading to better quality results. When businesses are better able to identify the human resources they need to drive their industry forward, the employment opportunities that are gained help to build strong communities. This positive cycle has a ripple effect on society, driving economic growth, creating new opportunities, and ultimately contributing to the establishment of thriving communities.


Last Modified: 06/06/2023
Modified by: Nicholas Hathaway
